title: Yahya Sinwar, Leader of Hamas, Is Dead
abstract: Mr. Sinwar climbed the ranks of the Palestinian militant group to plot the deadliest attack on Israel in its history.

multimedia.caption: Yahya Sinwar, the leader of Hamas, greeting the audience at the International Quds Day festival in Gaza City in 2023.
multimedia.copyright: Samar Abu Elouf for The New York Times

title: Sinwar Is Dead. Will the Fighting Stop?
abstract: The killing of Hamas’s leader may allow Israel to claim victory and agree to a cease-fire, and new Hamas leadership could be more open to compromise. But neither side is likely to immediately change course.

multimedia.caption: Families and supporters of hostages, some noting the death of the Hamas leader Yahya Sinwar, demonstrated in favor of a truce in Tel Aviv, on Thursday.
Families and supporters of hostages, some noting the death of the Hamas leader Yahya Sinwar, demonstrated in favor of a truce in Tel Aviv, on Thursday.
Families and supporters of hostages, some noting the death of the Hamas leader Yahya Sinwar, demonstrated in favor of a truce in Tel Aviv, on Thursday.

title: Sinwar Evaded Israeli Intelligence for Years. Military Trainees Came Upon Him.
abstract: A unit from the Israeli military encountered Yahya Sinwar, the leader of Hamas, while on an operation in southern Gaza, Israeli defense officials said.
byline: By Ronen Bergman and Aaron Boxerman

multimedia.caption: An Israeli military vehicle driving along the border of Gaza, on Thursday.
An Israeli military vehicle driving along the border of Gaza, on Thursday.
An Israeli military vehicle driving along the border of Gaza, on Thursday.

title: How Accurate, or Off-Target, Could the Polls Be This Year?
abstract: Pre-election polls will never perfectly match election results. But an examination of three decades of polling helps put recent misses into context.
byline: By Kaleigh Rogers, Albert Sun and Christine Zhang

title: Trump’s Rambling Speeches Focus His Critics and Worry His Allies
abstract: Some advisers and allies of former President Donald J. Trump are concerned about his scattershot style on the campaign trail as he continues to veer off script.

multimedia.caption: Donald J. Trump has defended the many digressions he takes during his interviews and speeches, calling it “the weave.”

title: In Rambling Interview, Trump Blames Zelensky, Not Putin, for Ukraine War
abstract: The war began when Russia invaded Ukraine, but Donald J. Trump said on a podcast that the Ukrainian president “should never have let that war start.”

multimedia.caption: Former President Donald J. Trump and President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine met last month at Trump Tower in Manhattan.

title: Is Hugh Grant’s Most Convincing Character ‘Hugh Grant’?
abstract: The seemingly droll, breezy star is actually sentimental about his family and utterly serious about his work, including his villainous turn in “Heretic.”
byline: By Sarah Lyall and Dana Scruggs

title: U.S. Wrestles With Aiding Allies and Maintaining Its Own Weapons Supply
abstract: Pentagon officials discuss whether the flow of assistance could be hurting the military’s ability to respond to a new conflict.
byline: By Helene Cooper and Eric Schmitt

title: Meloni’s Balancing Act: Centrist Abroad, Right Wing at Home
abstract: New policies on surrogate births and the treatment of asylum seekers, while largely symbolic, are designed to shore up her right-wing flank in Italy, analysts say.

multimedia.caption: The Italian prime minister, Giorgia Meloni, at a session in Rome related to an upcoming European Council meeting. She has moved away from her past association with hard-right politics.
The Italian prime minister, Giorgia Meloni, at a session in Rome related to an upcoming European Council meeting. She has moved away from her past association with hard-right politics.

title: Court Orders Delay of Execution in Texas Shaken Baby Case
abstract: Robert Roberson was set to be executed on Thursday evening for the death of his 2-year-old child. But state legislators obtained a last-minute court order postponing it.

multimedia.caption: A bipartisan group of Texas lawmakers at a September news conference calling on the Texas Board of Pardons and Paroles to grant clemency for Robert Roberson at the State Capitol in Austin.

title: A New Plan to Transform Newark Airport ‘From Worst to Best’
abstract: The plan, announced Thursday by the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, includes replacing the rickety AirTrain network and the airport’s dilapidated Terminal B.

title: What We Know About Liam Payne’s Death
abstract: A hotel desk manager called 911 with concerns about Payne, the former One Direction singer, shortly before he fell from a third-floor balcony. The results of toxicology reports are pending.
byline: By Emmanuel Morgan and Lucía Cholakian Herrera

multimedia.caption: Liam Payne, a former singer in One Direction, died on Wednesday after falling from a hotel in Buenos Aires.
Liam Payne, a former singer in One Direction, died on Wednesday after falling from a hotel in Buenos Aires.

title: One Direction Members Pay Tribute to Liam Payne With Emotional Remembrances
abstract: After hearing the news of Payne’s fatal fall from a hotel balcony, his groupmates, fans and collaborators shared their shock and grief.
byline: By Lucía Cholakian Herrera and Maya Salam

multimedia.caption: Fans gathered to mourn the death of the singer Liam Payne, formerly of the band One Direction, in Buenos Aires on Wednesday night.

title: Mitzi Gaynor, Leading Lady of Movie Musicals, Is Dead at 93
abstract: She was best known for starring in the 1958 screen version of “South Pacific.” But her Hollywood career was brief, and she soon shifted her focus to Las Vegas and TV.

multimedia.caption: Mitzi Gaynor in the 1958 film version of the Broadway musical “South Pacific.” Doris Day and Elizabeth Taylor were among the actresses considered for the role of Nellie Forbush before Ms. Gaynor was cast.

title: Father and Son Indicted on Murder Charges for Georgia School Shooting
abstract: A grand jury handed up charges against Colt Gray, 14, who is accused of killing four people at his high school. His father, Colin Gray, is accused of giving him access to the murder weapon.

multimedia.caption: Two teachers and two students were killed in the shooting at Apalachee High School in Winder, Ga.

title: How the Biden Team Plans to Build Peace From Sinwar’s Death
abstract: Will Israel take steps toward a Palestinian state?

title: This Is What It Takes to Get an Abortion in America
abstract: In text messages, videos, voice memos and pictures, we hear from the people at the frontlines of abortion access about how their worlds have changed.
des_facet: Dobbs v Jackson Women's Health Organization (Supreme Court Decision)

title: Trump Picked the Wrong Moment to Complain About a Language Barrier
abstract: But his description of the problems he sees with Haitian immigrants helps explain his monochrome vision of American life.

title: Behind Nigeria’s Deadliest Road Incident in Years, a Quest for Cheap Fuel
abstract: More than 160 people died when an overturned fuel tanker in northern Nigeria exploded. Witnesses and relatives of victims said poverty had driven most to try to collect the spilled gas.
byline: By Ismail Auwal and Elian Peltier

multimedia.caption: Victims of a tanker explosion receive treatment inside an ambulance at the Aminu Kano teaching hospital in Kano, Nigeria, on Wednesday.

title: These Tiny Worms Account for at Least 4 Nobel Prizes
abstract: A staple in laboratories worldwide, C. elegans is “an experimental dream,” said one scientist.

title: ‘A Rip-Off’: Students Secure a Final Settlement Against Walden University
abstract: A $28.5 million settlement in a class-action lawsuit against the university helped create a fresh precedent for prosecuting predatory advertising in for-profit education.
byline: By Zach Montague and Erica L. Green

title: Art Show of the Season? It’s These Centuries-Old Italian Paintings
abstract: The glowing works from Siena, now at the Met, are revelatory for their emotional intensity and 24-karat beauty.

multimedia.caption: Pietro Lorenzetti’s three-level “Tarlati Altarpiece” from about 1320 in the exhibition “Siena: The Rise of Painting: 1300-1350.” Tempera on wood, it traveled from a church in Arezzo to the Met.
multimedia.copyright: George Etheredge for The New York Times
